intro: Baccharis pululahuensis, commonly known as the Huallayá shrub, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in high-altitude grasslands. Its leaves are usually narrow and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and clustered. Baccharis pululahuensis plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various insects and birds.
